skill.name: brainstorming-features
skill.description: Facilitates creative ideation sessions for mobile and web app features, generating structured ideas with user stories, technical considerations, and implementation suggestions. Use when planning new features, exploring product direction, generating app ideas, feature discovery, product brainstorming, or when user mentions 'brainstorm', 'ideate', 'app ideas', or 'feature suggestions'.
skill.summary: Structured ideation skill for generating mobile and web app feature ideas with user stories and technical considerations.
skill.author: Emz1998

security_audit.summary: All 24 static findings are false positives. The scanner misidentified markdown code block delimiters as shell commands, technology references as browser storage access, template text as cryptographic algorithms, and prioritization logic as system reconnaissance. This is pure documentation with no executable code or security risks.

high_findings.title: Markdown Code Block Delimiters Falsely Flagged as Shell Commands
high_findings.description: Static scanner detected 'Ruby/shell backtick execution' at 13 locations (lines 71-241). These are markdown code block delimiters (```), not command execution backticks. The file is documentation, not executable code.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Triple backticks are markdown syntax for code blocks, not Ruby/shell command execution. No command execution occurs in this documentation file.

high_findings.title: Technology Reference Falsely Flagged as Browser Storage Access
high_findings.description: Static scanner detected 'Browser storage access' at line 191. Line 191 references IndexedDB/Dexie as a technology suggestion in an example feature description. This is documentation, not code accessing browser storage.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: IndexedDB/Dexie is mentioned as a technology option for flashcard storage. No actual browser storage access code exists in this documentation file.

high_findings.title: Template Text Falsely Flagged as Weak Cryptographic Algorithms
high_findings.description: Static scanner flagged lines 3, 29, 74, 75, 137, 138, 171, 244, 319 as 'weak cryptographic algorithms'. These lines contain benign template text such as 'One-line description', section headers, and feature descriptions. No cryptographic code exists in this file.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Scanner pattern-matched on benign text. These are documentation headers and descriptions, not cryptographic algorithm implementations.

high_findings.title: Prioritization Logic Falsely Flagged as System Reconnaissance
high_findings.description: Static scanner flagged line 127 as 'System reconnaissance'. Line 127 contains the text 'Low Value, High Effort â†’ Avoid' which is part of a prioritization matrix, not system reconnaissance code.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: This is a business logic classification for feature prioritization, not any form of system reconnaissance or information gathering.

content.value_statement: Planning new app features requires structured ideation. This skill generates actionable feature concepts with user stories, technical considerations, and implementation complexity scores to accelerate product development.
actual_capabilities: Generates structured feature ideas with user stories and technical considerations
Offers multiple brainstorming methods (Problem-First, Opportunity-First, Competitive Analysis, User Journey Mapping)
Creates feature briefs with prioritization matrices and success metrics
Produces concise feature lists and feature roadmap organization
Delivers actionable output ready for product team review
limitations: Requires user-provided context about app type, tech stack, and target users
Does not include market research or competitive analysis data
Generated ideas require human validation for business relevance
Does not design user interfaces or create technical specifications

use_cases.title: Startup MVP Planning
use_cases.description: Founders use this skill to rapidly generate feature ideas for their minimum viable product, ensuring they focus on high-impact features that deliver core value to early adopters.

use_cases.title: Product Team Feature Discovery
use_cases.description: Product managers use the skill to facilitate feature discovery workshops, generating structured ideas that can be evaluated against business goals and technical constraints.

use_cases.title: App Enhancement Sessions
use_cases.description: Developers use the skill to explore new features for existing applications, receiving technical considerations and implementation complexity guidance for each idea.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Feature Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate 5 feature ideas for a [app type] that helps [target users] achieve [main goal]. Keep it simple with one-line descriptions.
prompt_templates.scenario: When user wants a fast list of ideas without detailed context

prompt_templates.title: Detailed Feature Brief
prompt_templates.prompt: Create detailed feature briefs for 3 features for a [app type] built with [tech stack]. Target users are [user personas]. Focus on [specific problem area]. Include user stories, technical considerations, and implementation complexity.
prompt_templates.scenario: When user needs comprehensive feature documentation

prompt_templates.title: Competitive Analysis Session
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze typical features for [app category] apps and generate 5 unique feature ideas that would differentiate a new app from competitors. Explain how each creates competitive advantage.
prompt_templates.scenario: When user wants to explore market differentiation

prompt_templates.title: Constrained Ideation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate feature ideas for a [app type] with these constraints: tech stack is [stack], budget is [budget], timeline is [timeline]. Focus on [specific goals] and provide effort estimates for each idea.
prompt_templates.scenario: When user has specific technical or resource constraints

output_examples.input: Generate 3 feature ideas for a meditation app that helps beginners build a daily practice habit.
output: **Feature: Guided Morning Session** - Short 5-minute guided meditations with reminder integration [Complexity: Low]
**Feature: Streak Rewards System** - Visual progress tracking with milestone badges for consecutive practice days [Complexity: Medium]
**Feature: Mood-Based Recommendations** - AI-powered session suggestions based on user mood check-ins [Complexity: High]

output_examples.input: Brainstorm features for an e-commerce checkout flow improvement.
output_examples.output:
## Feature: One-Click Reorder

**One-line description:** Save previous orders as templates for instant reordering with a single tap.

**Problem it solves:** Returning customers waste time re-selecting items they buy repeatedly.

**User story:** As a returning customer, I want to reorder my previous purchases with one click so that I can quickly restock items without browsing.

**Technical considerations:** Order history API integration, template storage in user profile, inventory check before reorder, payment token reuse.

**Implementation complexity:** Low - Leverages existing order and payment infrastructure.

best_practices: Provide specific context about your app type, target users, and goals to receive focused, relevant ideas.
Iterate on ideas by adding technical constraints or business goals to refine the output.
Use the structured feature brief format when ideas need to be reviewed by engineering or stakeholders.
anti_patterns: Asking for feature ideas without providing any context about the app or users.
Ignoring the technical considerations and implementation complexity guidance provided.
Accepting generated ideas without validating against actual user needs and business goals.

faq.question: What context should I provide for best results?
faq.answer: Share the app type (mobile, web, PWA), target users, tech stack, core value proposition, and any specific problems you want to solve. More context produces more relevant ideas.

faq.question: Can this skill create full product requirements?
faq.answer: No. The skill generates feature ideas with user stories and technical considerations. Full product requirements need additional detail from product managers and stakeholders.

faq.question: How many features should I generate at once?
faq.answer: Start with 5-10 ideas in concise format, then select 3-5 for detailed exploration. This prevents overwhelming analysis while ensuring you capture diverse possibilities.

faq.question: Does this skill analyze competitor apps?
faq.answer: No. The skill can suggest features based on common patterns, but it does not access external data or analyze specific competitor applications.

faq.question: How does implementation complexity work?
faq.answer: Complexity reflects estimated development effort: Low (days), Medium (1-2 weeks), High (weeks to months). Factors include integration needs, new technology, and architectural changes.

faq.question: Can I use this for existing features?
faq.answer: Yes. Describe the current feature and what problem or enhancement you want. The skill can suggest improvements, complementary features, or alternative approaches.
